navigation.title: Match Numbers 1
navigation.outcome: Drag and drop the numbers 1-5 in the puzzle. Child becomes familiar with Number Symbols and Names. They also count and match objects, which enhances the subitizing skills in children.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Match Numbers 2
navigation.outcome: Children learn to count numbers on fingers. They also count and match objects, which enhances the subitizing skills in children.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Number Series
navigation.outcome: Children learn about orders of numbers in relation to other numbers shown. The lesson is developed to help students understand and be able to perform simple tasks of sequencing and placing numbers in a specific order so that they can move on to perform more complex tasks requiring this particular skill in future.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.outcome: The lesson handles number '6' individually which includes saying the number name, writing the number, counting, and recognizing a number of objects for '6'.

navigation.title: Match Numbers 1
navigation.outcome: The lesson helps in mapping a certain number of concrete objects to their corresponding numeric value. Also, children hone Subitizing: the skill of counting quickly and accurately by counting groups of objects stacked together.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Match Numbers 2
navigation.outcome: The lesson helps in mapping a certain number of concrete objects to their corresponding numeric value. Also, children hone Subitizing: the skill of counting quickly and accurately by counting groups of objects stacked together.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Match Numbers 3
navigation.outcome: The lesson introduces children to counting in groups on dice, dominoes and fingers. It also helps in mapping a certain number of concrete objects to their corresponding numeric value. Also, children hone Subitizing: the skill of counting quickly and accurately by counting groups of objects stacked together.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Match Numbers 4
navigation.outcome: The lesson helps in mapping a certain number of concrete objects to their corresponding numeric value. Also, children hone Subitizing: the skill of counting quickly and accurately by counting groups of objects stacked together.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Match Numbers 5
navigation.outcome: The lesson introduces children to counting in groups on dice and dominoes. It also helps in mapping a certain number of concrete objects to their corresponding numeric value. Also, children hone Subitizing: the skill of counting quickly and accurately by counting groups of objects stacked together.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Number Order 1-5
navigation.outcome: This lesson is a numeric game through which children learn the ordering, seriation and basic sequencing of numbers 6-10. The methodology involved is in simple puzzle format. Numbers are arranged in ascending order on a board. Few numbers are removed to create vacant spots in the sequence which is to be filled by the child to complete the puzzle. With practice they gain the ability not only to identify the order of cardinal numbers placement, but also grasp the sequence in their pattern.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Number Order 6-10
navigation.outcome: This lesson is a numeric game through which children learn the ordering, seriation and basic sequencing of numbers 6-10. The methodology involved is in simple puzzle format. Numbers are arranged in ascending order on a board. Few numbers are removed to create vacant spots in the sequence which is to be filled by the child to complete the puzzle. With practice they gain the ability not only to identify the order of cardinal numbers placement, but also grasp the sequence in their pattern.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Number Series 1-8
navigation.outcome: Being able to observe, recall, and sequence numbers in a specific order is an important math skill. In this lesson, children learn about orders of numbers (1-8) in relation to other numbers shown.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Number Series 6-9
navigation.outcome: Being able to observe, recall, and sequence numbers in a specific order is an important math skill. In this lesson, children learn about orders of numbers (6-9) in relation to other numbers shown.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Number Series 7-10
navigation.outcome: Being able to observe, recall, and sequence numbers in a specific order is an important math skill. In this lesson, children learn about orders of numbers (7-10) in relation to other numbers shown.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Number Series 1- 9
navigation.outcome: This lesson is a numeric game through which children learn the ordering, seriation and basic sequencing of numbers 1-9. The methodology involved is in simple puzzle format. Numbers are arranged in ascending order on a board. Few numbers are removed to create vacant spots in the sequence which is to be filled by the child to complete the puzzle. With practice they gain the ability not only to identify the order of cardinal numbers placement, but also grasp the sequence in their pattern.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Big to Small
navigation.outcome: Children are introduced to arranging numbers in descending order through simple and engaging puzzles.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Shapes 1
navigation.outcome: Introduces circle, square, triangle and rectangle shapes to children. Students learn that the shape doesn't change with size.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Shapes 2
navigation.outcome: Introduces circle, square, triangle and rectangle shapes to children. Students learn that the shape doesn't change with size or colour of an object. They also relate real life objects to geometrical shapes.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Shapes 3
navigation.outcome: Children learn to identify real life objects with the geometric shape name. For example Window = square, cookie = circle, etc.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Shapes 4
navigation.outcome: Children learn to identify real-life objects with the geometric shape name. For example Window = square, cookie = circle, etc. They also learn to read the names by matching them with similar shapes.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Puzzle Time
navigation.outcome: Children connect the associated numbers by matching them in the puzzle. The puzzles require drag and drop action which involves the fine-motor skills of isolating the index finger for selecting, dragging, and dropping puzzle pieces. It also helps in imporving their writing skills along with instilling concrete math sense in learners.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Number Series
navigation.outcome: Children learn about orders of numbers in relation to other numbers shown. The lesson is developed to help students understand and be able to perform simple tasks of sequencing and placing numbers in a specific order so that they can move on to perform more complex tasks requiring this particular skill in future.

navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Puzzle Time 91-100
navigation.outcome: Children solve puzzles of numbers 91-100. It reinforces their learning of numbers in addition to the practice in the ordering of numbers.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Write 91-100
navigation.outcome: Write numbers from 91-100 by tracing it on a given path.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Number Order
navigation.outcome: This lesson is a numeric game through which children learn the ordering, seriation and basic sequencing of numbers 6-10. The methodology involved is in simple puzzle format. Numbers are arranged in ascending order on a board. Few numbers are removed to create vacant spots in the sequence which is to be filled by the child to complete the puzzle. With practice they gain the ability not only to identify the order of cardinal numbers placement, but also grasp the sequence in their pattern.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Big & Small 1-5
navigation.outcome: Children write numbers in order of small to big and big to small. It is important for children to learn both the ascending and descending order of numbers since numbers move in both directions on the number line based on the mathematic operation.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Compare With 10
navigation.outcome: Children will compare the numbers with '10' and understand the relastionship between them as either, bigger, smaller or equal to.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Count and Compare
navigation.outcome: In the lesson, the child has to select the greater than, less than or equal sign to correctly compare the numbers and objects on each side of the weighing machine. The child will also add/subtract numbers for comparison. It will also will also familiarize children with the symbols - =, < and > (is equal to, smaller than and greater than).
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Big & Small 1-10
navigation.outcome: Children are introduced to arranging numbers (1-10) in descending order through simple and engaging puzzles.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Arrange Numbers 1-100
navigation.outcome: The lesson is based on100s a chart; a simple chequered chart, 10-by-10 grid, with the numbers one to one hundred arranged in the squares. Number sense is developed in children basically through the number line and introduction of base ten blocks. 100s chart is a combination of both, the number line and base 10 blocks, in a very simple format. Children envision the numbers which are arranged in groups of ten which helps them to visualize the number patterns of tens and ones in both horizontal and vertical directions.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: 3D shapes
navigation.outcome: 3D shapes are presented to children from different angles. By matching similar objects by identification of their common properties, a child develops skills which can be applied in future to identify congruent or similar triangles, working problems of sets and many more math problems.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Add 1
navigation.outcome: Simple addition of additing '1' to a number. Working with different forms of addition, the child will gain a thorough understanding of the concept of addition. The images and visuals aids in the Chimple app can have a huge impact on how students retain information.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Add 2
navigation.outcome: Simple addition of additing '2' to a number. Working with different forms of addition, the child will gain a thorough understanding of the concept of addition. The images and visuals aids in the Chimple app can have a huge impact on how students retain information.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Add 3 and 4
navigation.outcome: Simple addition of additing numbers '3' and '4' to a number. Working with different forms of addition, the child will gain a thorough understanding of the concept of addition. The images and visuals aids in the Chimple app can have a huge impact on how students retain information.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Quick Addition 1
navigation.outcome: Chimple uses interactive lessons to help students understand the basics of addition. The questions are presented in short quiz format.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Quick Addition 2
navigation.outcome: Chimple uses interactive lessons to help students understand the basics of addition. The questions are presented in short quiz format.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Quick Addition 3
navigation.outcome: Chimple uses interactive lessons to help students understand the basics of addition. The questions are presented in short quiz format.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Count and Add -1
navigation.outcome: In this lesson, a part of the equation is already given. The jars have fruits in specific numbers placed below. The child drags the jars to complete the equation counting objects inside the jars. Children learn to use numbers, including written numerals, to represent quantities and to solve a quantitative problems.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Count and Add -2
navigation.outcome: In this lesson, a part of the equation is already given. The jars have fruits in specific numbers placed below. The child drags the jars to complete the equation counting objects inside the jars. Children learn to use numbers, including written numerals, to represent quantities and to solve a quantitative problems.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Subtract 1
navigation.outcome: Children learn subtraction as an independent math operation, without relating it to addition. Here they take away just '1' from a number to learn basics of subtraction.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Subtract 2
navigation.outcome: Children learn subtraction as an independent math operation, without relating it to addition. Here they take away just '2' from a number to learn basics of subtraction.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Subtract 3 & 4
navigation.outcome: The lesson progresses a bit higher than basics. Here they take away '3' or '4'' from a number to learn basics of subtraction.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Count & Subtract 1
navigation.outcome: Counting and subtracting helps children understand the concept of subtraction.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Count & Subtract 2
navigation.outcome: Counting and subtracting helps children understand the concept of subtraction. Here children will subtract '2' from a number.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Speed Subtraction 1
navigation.outcome: Speed subtraction helps children subtract without counting objects, depending on their acquired knowledge of numbers.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Speed Subtraction 2
navigation.outcome: Speed subtraction helps children subtract without counting objects, depending on their acquired knowledge of numbers.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Write 100-110
navigation.outcome: Write number from 100 -110 by tracing it on a given path.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Number Order
navigation.outcome: Includes both ascending and descending order of 3 digit numbers. Children fill the blank space with the right number in the sequence.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.outcome: Place value of numbers 1-20. Children need to understand the place value of numbers in the Base 10 system. In this lesson, students can use the virtual blocks, rods, or flats to represent the numbers they see on the board and physically add or remove pieces to get the desired number. This fortifies their skill in the addition and subtraction of whole numbers. They also explore numbers in their increasing and decreasing orders.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Small to Big
navigation.outcome: Fill the missing number to complete the series of two-digit numbers arranged in ascending order.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Big to Small
navigation.outcome: Fill the missing number to complete the series of two-digit numbers arranged in descending order.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Skip by 2's
navigation.outcome: By working on the exercises in this lesson, children notice the numerical patterns of skip counting by 2's. The more patterns they see in numbers the more generalizations they can make about how numbers work. The skill is highly needed for them for working out math problems and when they move to higher computations.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: More Skip by 2's
navigation.outcome: By working on the exercises in this lesson, children notice the numerical patterns of skip counting by 2's. The more patterns they see in numbers the more generalizations they can make about how numbers work. The skill is highly needed for them for working out math problems and when they move to higher computations.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Count Backwards
navigation.outcome: Counting backward is an important strategy that children will later use in solving subtraction problems. Through the number series, number order and big to small lessons, children are counting forward and backward which helps to develop understanding of relative size and how numbers are related to one another.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Place Value 100-300
navigation.outcome: Place value of numbers 100-300. Children need to understand the place value of numbers in the Base 10 system. In this lesson, students can use the virtual blocks, rods, or flats to represent the numbers they see on the board and physically add or remove pieces to get the desired number. This fortifies their skill in the addition and subtraction of whole numbers. They also explore numbers in their increasing and decreasing orders.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Place Value 300-500
navigation.outcome: Place value of numbers 300-500. Children need to understand the place value of numbers in the Base 10 system. In this lesson, students can use the virtual blocks, rods, or flats to represent the numbers they see on the board and physically add or remove pieces to get the desired number. This fortifies their skill in the addition and subtraction of whole numbers. They also explore numbers in their increasing and decreasing orders.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.outcome: Place value of numbers 100-500. Children need to understand the place value of numbers in the Base 10 system. In this lesson, students can use the virtual blocks, rods, or flats to represent the numbers they see on the board and physically add or remove pieces to get the desired number. This fortifies their skill in the addition and subtraction of whole numbers. They also explore numbers in their increasing and decreasing orders.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Even Numbers
navigation.outcome: Teaches the concept of even numbers.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Odd Numbers
navigation.outcome: Teaches the concept of odd numbers.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Shapes Advanced
navigation.outcome: Children learn names of shapes like Hexagon, parallelogram, rhombus etc
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: 2D & 3D Shapes
navigation.outcome: Children match and learn names and appearance of advanced shapes.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Shapes and Solids
navigation.outcome: Children match the geometric shapes to real-life objects.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Addition Beginners
navigation.outcome: Since children typically see a quantity as an aggregate of single units, they need to count when finding the total or to subtract a quantity from an aggregate. The game helps the child by giving visual clues and objects to count to find the correct answer. Counting helps the child to know that the larger number is made of parts of smaller numbers
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Addition
navigation.outcome: Since children typically see a quantity as an aggregate of single units, they need to count when finding the total or to subtract a quantity from an aggregate. The game helps the child by giving visual clues and objects to count to find the correct answer. Counting helps the child to know that the larger number is made of parts of smaller numbers
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Count & Add 1
navigation.outcome: When children count and add they understand the quantity the numbers represent. It will help them add and learn the meaning of numbers as well. The concept of addition is made simple by counting.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Count & Add 2
navigation.outcome: When children count and add they understand the quantity the numbers represent. It will help them add and learn the meaning of numbers as well. The concept of addition is made simple by counting.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Family of 10
navigation.outcome: Children become familiar with numbers that when summed together will form the number '10'. Eg. 8+2. 4+6 etc
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Quick Addition 1-10
navigation.outcome: This lesson offers equations in the form of short quiz-like questions of addition for evaluation and practice for students besides helping to assess their comprehension of the math concept. No counting is given.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Addition 1
navigation.outcome: The child solves a simple equation of either addition and clicks on the right answer to progress to the next activity. If the child clicks on the wrong answer it disappears so that the next choice will be from a lesser quantity of numbers.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Addition 2
navigation.outcome: The child solves a simple equation of either addition and clicks on the right answer to progress to the next activity. If the child clicks on the wrong answer it disappears so that the next choice will be from a lesser quantity of numbers.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Addition 3
navigation.outcome: The child solves a simple equation of either addition and clicks on the right answer to progress to the next activity. If the child clicks on the wrong answer it disappears so that the next choice will be from a lesser quantity of numbers.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Addition Mastery
navigation.outcome: The child performs basic addition either mentally or if challenged by counting the objects presented in the boxes which hold the quantities in ten and dragging the right answer to its respective place.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Family Of 20 - 1
navigation.outcome: The lessons presents number equations that add to '20'
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Family Of 20 - 2
navigation.outcome: The lessons presents number equations that add to '20'
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Beginners Addition 1-20
navigation.outcome: Children add numbers between 1 - 20
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: More Addition 1-20
navigation.outcome: This lesson offers equations in the form of short quiz-like questions of addition (numbers 1-20)for evaluation and practice for students besides helping to assess their comprehension of the math concept. No counting is given.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Quick Addition 20
navigation.outcome: This lesson offers equations in the form of short quiz-like questions of addition for evaluation and practice for students besides helping to assess their comprehension of the math concept. No counting is given.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Addition 11-20
navigation.outcome: Children add numbers between 11 - 20
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Beginners 1
navigation.outcome: Children count and subtract single digit numbers. Research has proven that counting single units as the primary strategy for solving arithmetic tasks helps children develop basic computational skills.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Beginners 2
navigation.outcome: Children count and subtract single digit numbers. Research has proven that counting single units as the primary strategy for solving arithmetic tasks helps children develop basic computational skills.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Subtract From 10
navigation.outcome: Subtraction of numbers from 10 given in progressive order
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Count and Subtract 1
navigation.outcome: In this lesson, the child will count and subtract numbers. A part of the equation is already given. The jars have fruits in specific numbers placed below. The child drags the jars to complete the equation counting objects inside the jars. Children learn to use numbers, including written numerals, to represent quantities and to solve a quantitative problems.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Count and Subtract 2
navigation.outcome: Children count and subtract single digit numbers. Research has proven that counting single units as the primary strategy for solving arithmetic tasks helps children develop basic computational skills.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Count and Subtract 3
navigation.outcome: Children count and subtract single digit numbers. Research has proven that counting single units as the primary strategy for solving arithmetic tasks helps children develop basic computational skills.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Subtraction 1
navigation.outcome: Speed subtraction helps children subtract without counting objects, depending on their acquired knowledge of numbers.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Subtraction 2
navigation.outcome: Quick subtraction without objects to count. Improves skill of mental calculations in maths.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Subtraction 3
navigation.outcome: Quick subtraction without objects to count. Improves skill of mental calculations in maths.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: 10's Subtraction
navigation.outcome: Numbers are subtracted from '10' in progressive order.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Subtraction Mastery 1
navigation.outcome: The child performs basic subtraction either mentally or if challenged by counting the objects presented in the boxes which hold the quantities in ten and dragging the right answer to its respective place.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Subtraction Mastery 2
navigation.outcome: The child performs basic subtraction either mentally or if challenged by counting the objects presented in the boxes which hold the quantities in ten and dragging the right answer to its respective place.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Subtraction Mastery 3
navigation.outcome: The child performs basic subtraction either mentally or if challenged by counting the objects presented in the boxes which hold the quantities in ten and dragging the right answer to its respective place.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Subtract From 20
navigation.outcome: Repeat subtraction from the number 20 will reinforce the concept of subtraction in children.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Calculator 1
navigation.outcome: The lesson introduces an independent whiteboard for working out the subtraction sums to the student. The child uses a whiteboard provided to solve the subtraction problems and enters the answer on the number-board which is in the form of a traditional calculator.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en

navigation.title: Calculator 2
navigation.outcome: The lesson introduces an independent whiteboard for working out the subtraction sums to the student. The child uses a whiteboard provided to solve the subtraction problems and enters the answer on the number-board which is in the form of a traditional calculator.
navigation.subject: /Subject/en
